Applicability.--The program referred to in subsection is the program for which funds appropriated in title I of Public Law 106- 69 under the heading FEDERAL RAILROAD ADMINISTRATION'' are available. The Speaker of the House of Representatives is responsible for the enactment of legislation authorizing the program. The President of the Senate is responsible for the enactment of legislation authorizing the program.

That this Act may be cited as the Federal Forage Fee Act of 1993''. Findings.--Congress finds and declares that-- it is in the national interest that the public lands are producing and continue to produce water and soil conservation benefits, livestock forage. Wildlife forage and recreation and other multiple use opportunities are available in rangelands. Rangelands will continue to be stabilized and improved long term by providing for cooperative agreements, private, public. The stewardship of renewable resources requires partnerships and flexibility in management programs and agreements. To assure sound management and stewardship of the renewable resources it is imperative to charge a fee that is reasonable. The intermingled private-public land ownership patterns prevailing in much of the west create a strong interdependence between public and private land ownership. The fair value of the forage provided is equitable and represents the fair value of the forage provided. The social and economic infrastructure of many rural communities and stability of job opportunities in many areas of rural communities are important factors in the development of rural communities. Private lands are used for forage, water, and habitat for both wildlife and livestock. Rural America is highly independent on the protection of the value of privately held production units on Federal lands. Unless contrary to this statute, all grazing operations conducted on any Federal lands shall be subject to all applicable Federal, State, and local laws, including but not limited to: Animal Damage. Wilderness Act (78 Stat. 1269), as amended. The term Sixteen Western States'' means WA, CA, ID, NV, NM, WY, CO, KS, SD, ND, NE, OR, OK, AZ, UT and MT. Sixteen Western States'' is used for the purpose of this section. AUM'' means an animal unit month. The Public Rangeland Improvement Act (92 Stat. ) uses the term AUM. Authorized Federal AUMs'' means all allotted AUMs'' reported by BLM and permitted to graze AUMs'' reported by USFS. 1803); Authorized Federal AUMs'' means all allotted AUMs'' reported by BLM. WAPLLR'' means the weighted average private land lease rate determined by multiplying the private land lease rate reported by the Economic Research Service for the previous calendar year for each year. WAPLLR'' means the weighted average private land lease rate determined by the Economic Research Service. The total number of authorized Federal AUMs in each State for the previous fiscal year is divided by the total number of authorized Federal AUMs in each of the sixteen Western States. The total number of authorized Federal AUMs in each State is divided by the total number of authorized Federal AUMs for the previous fiscal year. The sixteen Western States are the authorized Federal AUMs. The sixteen Western States are then added together and divided by 16 to yield a weighted average private land lease rate for that year. Grazing Fee Review and Evaluation Update of the 1986 Final Report'' was prepared by the Departments of the Interior and Agriculture. Grazing Fee Review and Evaluation Update of the 1986 Final Report'' was dated 30 April 1992. Nonfee cost differential'' means a value calculated annually by the Secretaries by multiplying the weighted difference in nonfee costs per AUM between public land and private land by the Input Cost. Nonfee cost differential'' means a value calculated annually by the Secretaries by multiplying the weighted difference in nonfee costs per AUM between public land and private land by the Input Cost. Index is determined annually by the Department of Agriculture. The weighted difference in nonfee costs is 0.552. The weighted difference in nonfee costs is determined by deducting the private AUM nonfee costs (as outlined on page 58 of the report) from the public AUM nonfee costs for cattle. The result of deducting private AUM nonfee costs from public AUM nonfee costs for sheep is divided by 5. Net production differential'' is the percentage of the net production differential. Net production differential'' is the percentage of the net production differential. Cash receipts per cow are calculated annually by dividing the cash receipts per cow for Federal permittee livestock producers by the cash receipts per cow for western non-Federal livestock producers in the sixteen Western states. The cash receipts per cow for Federal permittee livestock producers is calculated by dividing the cash receipts per cow for Federal permittee livestock producers by the cash receipts per cow for western non-Federal livestock producers. The Economic Research Service surveyed the United States in annual cost of production surveys. PLFVR'' means the private land lease forage value ratio determined by dividing the average of the 1964-1968 base years' private land lease rate into the forage value portion of the private land lease. PLFVR'' means the private land lease forage value ratio determined by dividing the average of the 1964-1968 base years' private land lease rate into the forage value portion of the private land lease. The western livestock grazing survey was conducted in 1966. The western livestock grazing rate is $1.78. The Federal forage fee is calculated annually by calculating the average of the WALLPR for the preceding three years. The Secretaries of the Department of Agriculture and the Department of the Interior shall calculate the Federal forage fee by calculating the average of the WALLPR for the preceding three years. The nonfee cost differential is deducted from the nonfee cost differential. The nonfee cost differential is multiplied by the net production differential. For each year that this calculation is made, all data used for calculating this fee shall come from the calendar year preceding the year for which the fee is being calculated unless specified. Otherwise in the above calculations. The Federal forage fee shall apply to all authorized Federal AUMs under the jurisdiction of the United States Department of Agriculture. The United States Department of Agriculture is under the jurisdiction of the United States Department of the Interior. For the first year that the Secretaries calculate the Federal forage fee, the fee shall not be greater than 125 percent, or less than 75 percent of the fee calculated for the previous year pursuant to the Federal Forage Fee Act. For the first year that the Secretaries calculate the Federal forage fee, the fee shall not be greater than 125 percent, or less than 75 percent of the fee calculated for the previous year pursuant to the Federal Forage Fee Act. Executive Order 12548 was issued on February 14, 1986. For each year after the first year that the Secretaries calculate the Federal forage fee, the fee shall not be greater than 125 percent. For each year after the first year that the Secretaries calculate the Federal forage fee, the fee shall not be less than 75 percent of the Federal forage fee calculated. For the previous year. The survey of nonfee costs used to calculate the nonfee cost differential shall be updated periodically by the Secretaries so as to reflect as accurately as possible the actual nonfee costs incurred. The cattle and sheep industry utilizes public lands in the Western States. The cattle and sheep industry is one of the industries in the Western States. The results of the updated survey shall be incorporated into the calculation of the Non Fee Cost Differential.
